pr_title: [IPC part 4] test cases for IPC strategies.

timeline.bodyText: If this is going to be communicated, let's make it a String, so we aren't sharing any types that aren't constructible from the base platform.  Basically, that means any primitive, packaged (String, Integer, Map, List, Set...) or combination of only that.  And in this mechanism, we should specify what kinds of commands COULD be supported, so it might need to be a richer structure than just String, so that we can teach our clients how to respond to a failed attempt.
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: We're not communicating this to the other side of IPC. This is more or less to limit the scope of, and categorize the error code for BrokerCommunicationException.
replies.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: Added "StrategyType" into BrokerCommunicationException's argument list (so that it prints more details into the log).
replies.author: rpdome

timeline.bodyText: You don't need to check both, you know that they're equal...
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

timeline.bodyText: what if objB is null?
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

timeline.bodyText: OnjectUtils.equals...
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

timeline.bodyText: Should this go into a BundleUtils.java in testutils in common?
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: added testImplementation dependency to testutils and hell break loose.. will do that later.
replies.author: rpdome

timeline.bodyText: Here, can we discover what operations are supported?
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: Not at this point. In this layer we're focusing on Bound Service only (and it failed).
replies.author: rpdome

timeline.bodyText: This is a strange message.  How would you bind the wrong service?
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: It means you're using the wrong BoundServiceClient. will change to Wrong BoundServiceClient used.
replies.author: rpdome

timeline.bodyText: Here we want the first one to be executed and the second not to be interacted with at all, right?
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: yes. removing this though... I think it's kind of pointless. other test cases should be enough to cover 'strategy order'
replies.author: rpdome

timeline.bodyText: Should we distinguish "failure of strategy" from "failure to communicate" and make certain that this just does not execute the second one after the first attempt succeeds with false?
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText:
In this test suite, there are 4 possible outcomes.

Gets a bundle back, the bundle contains a valid result. The result returns true.
Gets a bundle back, the bundle contains a valid result. The result returns false.
Gets a bundle back, the bundle is invalid. (this is probably what you referred to as 'failure of Strategy')
Fails to get the bundle. (Failure to communicate)

I think I used bad wording here. This test case refers to 2)
replies.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: Come to think of it, I should just combine 1 and 2. It doesn't really matter in this layer.
replies.author: rpdome

timeline.bodyText: This is interesting.  If the result is corrupted, I think we'd want to fall back on the rest of the chain.
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText:
Corrupted here doesn't mean data loss during a transfer, that, AFAIK, never happens.
It means the broker is sending a result bundle with unexpected format, or the data is not properly compressed. The data is 'corrupted' from the source, therefore it doesn't matter which communication channel you use - you'll always get the same result bundle.
replies.author: rpdome

timeline.bodyText: In general, if the first one succeeds, the we don't want to run the other one at all, so it shouldn't matter what it does.  All of its methods can throw RuntimeException and it should have no effect, I think.
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: Yep. This test case is to make sure that the order of strategy matters.
replies.author: rpdome

timeline.bodyText: Same comment.
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

timeline.bodyText: We should have some of these throw other kinds of Exceptions and Error results.
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: added ServiceException and UserCancelException. (the other two main exceptions that inherited from BaseException - the executor can only throw BaseException)
replies.author: rpdome

timeline.bodyText: Should this return a List?
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: Please see the answer regarding parameterized test below.
replies.author: rpdome

timeline.bodyText: Can we make this into a parameterized test?
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText:
I assume you mean making IIpcStrategy the parameter in the parameterized test.

Each strategy requires different shadow classes.... so ... we could, but I don't want to put all shadow classes in one place.
I should mark all the test functions here abstract. Once we start supporting broker IPC, these tests will diverge. (it works with all the subclasses because we're working only on MSAL-Broker communication).
replies.author: rpdome

timeline.bodyText: Do we care if it's the same identity? (here and elsewhere)
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: same identity?
replies.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: AssertSame is a comparison of object identity, essentially memory address.  So my question is - is it important that it's the same object or should it just need to compare equals?
replies.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: ah ok. assertEquals makes more sense then. not sure why this is not throwing an error :/
replies.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: Because it's an enum. ;-)
replies.author: AdamBJohnsonx

timeline.bodyText: might be nice to parameterize this thing so you could make it throw them all by using a static factory that takes the exception to throw.
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

+import java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException;
+

+    protected @NonNull T connect(@NonNull final String targetServicePackageName)
+            throws ClientException, InterruptedException, TimeoutException, ExecutionException {
+        throw new TimeoutException("Connection timed out");

replies.bodyText: can you parameterize a shadow class? (I couldn't find a way to do so)
replies.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: I was thinking more about whether a shadow is the right way to deal with this, since BoundServiceClient is, I think, our own class.  We shouldn't need to use a shadow for it.
replies.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText:
we don't necessarily need shadow, but IMO it's easier/cleaner to implement this way.
Right now, each method are calling testOperationXXXXX(), and that function is pulling the strategy object from getStrategy(). If we don't use shadow, we would have to supply IIpcStrategy object in every methods, across all 3 strategies.
Shadowing allows us to easily modify the injected object in specific test cases.
replies.author: rpdome

timeline.bodyText: Does it matter what this returns?  If we're really expecting that it isn't called, throw UnsupportedOperationException and then you'll know if that idea changes.  If it is being called, what happenes if it doesn't return null?
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: We don't really use it here. (it should be used if we're doing the actual bind)
replies.author: rpdome

timeline.bodyText: Do we need to use a fake one?  Could we actually just pull a sample Bundle from the actual code?
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText:
I intentionally did not use the actual sample bundle - since that depends on the MSAL-Broker protocol.
This test case should be protocol-agnostic.
replies.author: rpdome

timeline.bodyText: We're shadowing our own class here.  There's probably a better way.
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx
